xxl.core.cursors
Interface Cursor<E>

Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Superinterfaces:

All Known Subinterfaces:

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractCursor, AbstractMetaDataCursor, AggregateGrouper, AggregateGrouper.CFDCursor, AggregateGrouper.DuplicatesRemover, Aggregator, Aggregator, ArrayCursor, AutomaticCloseCursor, ChannelCursor, ContinuousRandomNumber, CrossTableCursor, DBScan, DecoratorCursor, DelayCursor, DiscreteRandomNumber, Dropper, EmptyCursor, EnumerationCursor, Enumerator, FileInputCursor, FileNameCursor, Filter, Flatten, GESS, GroupAggregator, HashGrouper, HazardDelayManager, Inductor, InputStreamCursor, InputStreamMetaDataCursor, IteratorCursor, KPEInputCursor, LoggingMetaDataCursor, Mapper, Mapper, Merger, MergeSorter, MergeSorter, Minimator, MSJ, MSJ.MSJSorter, MultiWaySortMergeJoin, NestedLoopsDifference, NestedLoopsDifference, NestedLoopsDistinct, NestedLoopsDistinct, NestedLoopsGrouper, NestedLoopsGrouper, NestedLoopsIntersection, NestedLoopsIntersection, NestedLoopsJoin, NestedLoopsJoin, NestedLoopsJoin, NotUpdatableCursor, ObjectToBlockCursor, Orenstein, Orenstein, Orenstein.FloatPointKPEzCodeMapper, Permutator, PlaneSweep, PointInputCursor, PostponeUpdatesCursor, Projection, QueueCursor, RandomElementReservoirSampler, RandomRectangle, RectangleInputIterator, RectangleUniverseDouble, Remover, Renaming, Repeater, ReplacementSelection, Replicator, ReservoirSampler, ResetableCursor, ResultSetMetaDataCursor, Sampler, Sampler, SecureDecoratorCursor, Selection, Sequentializer, ShowKPERectanglesCursor, ShuffleCursor, SingleObjectCursor, SinkCursor, SortBasedDifference, SortBasedDifference, SortBasedDistinct, SortBasedDistinct, SortBasedDivision, SortBasedGrouper, SortBasedGrouper, SortBasedIntersection, SortBasedIntersection, SortMergeEquivalenceJoin, SortMergeJoin, SortMergeJoin, SortMergeSelfJoin, SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin, Subquery, Taker, TeeCursor, Union, UniverseDouble, UniverseFloat, UnmodifiableCursor, URLInputCursor, WhileDropper, WhileRemover, WhileTaker, XMLMetaDataCursor, XMLMetaDataCursor, ZipFileInputCursor
public interface Cursor<E>
extends Iterator<E>

A cursor extends the interface Iterator by adding functionality for opening and closing the cursor, i.e., reserving and releasing of system resources, taking a look at the next element that would be returned by call to next, updating elements of the underlying data structure and traversing it another time without constructing a new cursor.

Cursors differ from iterators in some points:

  • open: before using a cursor the caller must open it in order to reserve resources, open files, etc.
  • close: after using a cursor it must be closed by the caller in order to clean up resources, close files, etc.
  • peek: cursors allow the caller to show the next element in the iteration without proceeding the iteration.
  • supportsPeek: a method that returns true if an instance of a cursor supports the peek operation, otherwise it returns false.
  • supportsRemove: a method that returns true if an instance of a cursor supports the remove operation, otherwise it returns false.
  • update: cursors allow the caller to update the element in the iteration returned by the next or peek method and replacing it in the underlying collection.
  • supportsUpdate: a method that returns true if an instance of a cursor supports the update operation, otherwise it returns false.
  • reset: cursors allow the caller to traverse the underlying collection again without constructing a new cursor.
  • supportsReset: a method that returns true if an instance of a cursor supports the reset operation, otherwise it returns false.

General contract:
If an exception is thrown by a cursor consecutive calls to methods are not guaranteed to produce correct results.

Important: In order to guarantee a certain semantics, an implementation of a Cursor has to ensure that a call of hasNext always returns false after the first time false is delivered. Thus, it should not be possible to receive an element by calling hasNext and next at a later point in time, if hasNext returned false before (even if the underlying data structure received a new element meanwhile).

General order of method invocations: 

     // creating a new instance of an arbitrary cursor
 
     Cursor<Object> cursor = ...
 
     // opening the cursor for first use
 
     cursor.open();
 
     // consuming the cursor in a loop; checking if there is a next element
 
     while(cursor.hasNext()) {
 
         ...
 
         // taking a look at the next element, but do not remove it from the
         // underlying collection (optional)
 
         Object peek = cursor.peek();
 
         ...
 
         // consuming the next element
 
         Object next = cursor.next();
 
         ...
 
         // removing object 'next' from the underyling collection (optional)
 
         cursor.remove();
 
     }
 
     ...
 
     // cursor will be used again, so reset it (optional)
 
     cursor.reset();
 
     ...
 
     // cursor is not needed any more; release resources
 
     cursor.close();

See Also:
Iterator

          Returns true if the iteration has more elements.

          Returns the next element in the iteration.

          Shows the next element in the iteration without proceeding the iteration (optional operation).

          Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the cursor (optional operation).

          Returns true if the update operation is supported by the cursor.
 void update(E object)
          Replaces the last element returned by the cursor in the underlying data structure (optional operation).
 

Method Detail

open

void open()
Opens the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open files, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

close

void close()
Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close files, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

hasNext

boolean hasNext()
                throws IllegalStateException
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

This operation should be implemented idempotent, i.e., consequent calls to hasNext do not have any effect.

Important: In order to guarantee a certain semantics, an implementation of a Cursor has to ensure that a call of hasNext always returns false after the first time false is delivered. Thus, it should not be possible to receive an element by calling hasNext and next at a later point in time, if hasNext returned false before (even if the underlying data structure received a new element meanwhile).

Specified by:
hasNext in interface Iterator<E>
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.

next

E next()
       throws IllegalStateException,
              NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
next in interface Iterator<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

peek

E peek()
       throws IllegalStateException,
              NoSuchElementException,
              UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without proceeding the iteration (optional operation). After calling peek the returned element is still the cursor's next one such that a call to next would be the only way to proceed the iteration. But be aware that an implementation of this method uses a kind of buffer-strategy, therefore it is possible that the returned element will be removed from the underlying iteration, e.g., the caller can use an instance of a cursor depending on an iterator, so the next element returned by a call to peek will be removed from the underlying iterator which does not support the peek operation and therefore the iterator has to be wrapped and buffered.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors. After calling the peek method a call to next is strongly recommended.

Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsPeek

boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

remove

void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the cursor (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and removes the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and remove the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
remove in interface Iterator<E>
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsRemove

boolean supportsRemove()
Returns true if the remove operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Returns:
true if the remove operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

update

void update(E object)
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the last element returned by the cursor in the underlying data structure (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and updates the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and update the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the last element returned by the cursor.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the update method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsUpdate

boolean supportsUpdate()
Returns true if the update operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Returns:
true if the update operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

reset

void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsReset

boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.
